page.title: 02MEDIEVAL TIMES
page.content: North Kyme was,at one time,part of the area owned by{Philip of Kyme}who was a sheriff of Lincolnshire in the twelfth century. This lasted until the reign of Henry Vlll when the manor then belonged to Earl Fitzwilliam who sold it to various freeholders. It was at the eastern edge of a low fen farming area which was part of a great level drainage scheme undertaken by the Earl of Lincoln in 1653.In 1793 a turnpike road was built from Sleaford to Tattershall which opened up the area. A Wesleyan Chapel was built in 1848 and closed down in 1982. The ancient cross in the centre of the village known as the{Butter {Cross}was renovated in 1826 and was originally used as a meeting place for local farmers and their wives to sit and sell their produce.
